bibo:abstract.@value: Confronted with the establishment of Portugal and Spain as the hegemonic Atlantic powers, northern Europe — France, England, and the Netherlands — initially tried to obtain African and American riches by raiding and trading. Successful colonisation of the New World had to wait until the early seventeenth century, and settlements remained small until the 1640s. By then, northern Europe held sway in various parts of North America, the Caribbean, and Brazil, and had captured Portugal's main West African trading station. As raiders, traders, and settlers, they had formed relations with native Africans and Americans, who had often enabled them to survive. But prejudice against their new neighbours intensified. This article looks at the northern European Atlantic world, focusing on privateers, merchants, and fishermen as well as informal intermediaries.

Without the ocean — or rather, the two oceans, the North and South Atlantic — we cannot account for many of the basic facts of Atlantic history. Only ships and seafaring made possible the construction of the Atlantic world. Two stages in the making of the Atlantic world need to be distinguished; the age of exploration, when the geography of the two oceans was yet to be determined, and the age of exploitation which followed. Besides knowledge of celestial navigation and the wind systems, there was one further key element of the Atlantic navigation system which was developed in the fifteenth century: the three-masted ship rig. Just as the wind and current systems favoured the Spaniards in the Caribbean, they favoured the Portuguese in the South Atlantic Ocean. The study of Atlantic navigation raises as many questions as it answers. It seems to account for the early success of Portugal and Spain, but also seems to make almost impossible the rise to prominence in international trade of such remote and unfavoured ports as London and Amsterdam.

o:title: Cross-cultural Exchange in the Atlantic world: Angola and Brazil during the Era of the Slave Trade

dcterms:title.@value: Cross-cultural Exchange in the Atlantic world: Angola and Brazil during the Era of the Slave Trade

bibo:abstract.@value: Summary: "This book argues that Angola and Brazil were connected, not separated, by the Atlantic Ocean. Roquinaldo Ferreira focuses on the cultural, religious and social impacts of the slave trade on Angola. Reconstructing biographies of Africans and merchants, he demonstrates how cross-cultural trade, identity formation, religious ties and resistance to slaving were central to the formation of the Atlantic world. By adding to our knowledge of the slaving process, the book powerfully illustrates how Atlantic slaving transformed key African institutions, such as local regimes of forced labor that predated and coexisted with Atlantic slaving and made them fundamental features of the Atlantic world's social fabric"-- Provided by publisher.

o:title: An African Slaving port and the Atlantic world: Benguela and its Hinterland

dcterms:title.@value: An African Slaving port and the Atlantic world: Benguela and its Hinterland

bibo:abstract.@value: Summary: "This book traces the history and development of the port of Benguela, the third largest port of slave embarkation on the coast of Africa, from the early seventeenth to the mid-nineteenth century. Benguela, located on the central coast of present-day Angola, was founded by the Portuguese in the early seventeenth century. In discussing the impact of the trans-Atlantic slave trade on African societies, Mariana P. Candido explores the formation of new elites, the collapse of old states, and the emergence of new states. Placing Benguela in an Atlantic perspective, this study shows how events in the Caribbean and Brazil affected social and political changes on the African coast. This book emphasizes the importance of the South Atlantic as a space for the circulation of people, ideas, and crops"-- Provided by publisher.

o:title: Ouidah: The Social History of a West African Slaving 'port', 1727-1892

dcterms:title.@value: Ouidah: The Social History of a West African Slaving 'port', 1727-1892

bibo:abstract.@value: Ouidah, an indigenous African town in the modern Republic of Benin, was the principal pre-colonial commercial centre of its region, and the second most important town of the Dahomey kingdom. It served as a major outlet for the export of slaves for the trans- Atlantic trade. Between the seventeenth and the nineteenth centuries Ouidah was the most important embarkation point for slaves in the region of West Africa known to outsiders as the 'Slave Coast'. Exporting over a million slaves, it was second only to Luanda in Angola for the embarkation of slaves in the whole of Africa. The author's central concerns are the organization of the African end of the slave trade, and the impact participation in the trade had on the historical development of the African societies involved. It shifts the focus from the viewpoint of the Dahomian monarchy, represented in previous studies, to the coast. Here is a well documented case study of pre-colonial urbanism, of the evolution of a merchant community, and in particular the growth of a group of private traders whose relations with the Dahomian monarchy grew increasingly problematic over time. North America: Ohio U Press

acm5air:note.@value:
Summary of Schwartz, Stuart B. “The Iberian Atlantic to 1650.” In The Oxford Handbook of the Atlantic World: 1450-1850, edited by Nicholas Canny and Philip Morgan. Oxford University Press, 2011.
Bruno Buccalon
Summary

Summary of Schwartz, Stuart B. The Iberian Atlantic to 1650. Edited by Nicholas Canny and Philip Morgan. Vol. 1. Oxford University Press, 2012. https://doi.org/10.1093/oxfordhb/9780199210879.013.0009.
Schwartz traces Castilian (also referred to as Spanish) and Portuguese control of the Atlantic, arguing that through both competition and cooperation, these powers formed the first "systems of continual communication, trade and political control" up until 1650. The "Iberian Atlantic" is presented as the original European empire in the Atlantic. The article traces the main processes by which both Portugal and Spain moved from establishing trade outposts on the shoreline to increasingly robust settlement beginning the Caribbean, then moving into the Americas. The Castilian presence in the New World and Portuguese outposts along the West African enabled the Iberian Atlantic to form, even to the extent that at one point both countries were ruled by a "composite monarchy" from 1580-1640 (Schwartz 147).
The Iberian Atlantic economy began through trade and settlement. The Spanish plundered local wealth and coerced the indigenous into mining ventures as part of the settlement economy, which remained a key source of Spanish income well into the mid-17th century. The initial Caribbean mining projects declined necessitating expansion into Central America. Indigenous populations were displaced from the shores and interior groups migrated to urban centres to participate in waged mining labor that continually expanded in Mexico (Zacatecas, 1546; Guanajuato, c.1550) and in Peru (Potosí, 1545) from the middle of the 16th Century. The value of "exports of precious metals" eclipsed "all other American products" combined but only involved direct participation of "15 percent" of the population, while the urban centers and or transport networks utilized created peripheral centers of labor and commerce. The wealth produced from this export "maintained Spain's credit and allowed the monarchy to pursue a previously unthinkable foreign policy and imperial project" (158). While the Iberian empire was constructed by both Spain and Portugal, but their colonization processes differed significantly.
 Schwartz offers geographical distance as one reason, other than financial incentive, that Spanish colonization was quicker than Portuguese. Travel time between Portugal and Brazil was shorter than between Spain and its colonies made easier by the Portuguese presence in Africa. Geographic and infrastructural proximity to Brazil meant the colony was more easily managed as an "extension of Portugal" (158). Spain established several institutions to manage and limit the increasing independence of settlers in the America, independence arisen from colonial wealth. They established a House of Trade in 1503 and Council of the Indies in 1523 to regulate Atlantic trade from the Castilian metropole, suggesting that increasing colonial power independent of the crown posed a threat to monarchical control of the Americas early in Spanish colonization. Ultimately, colonial control required cooperation between national and private interests. Metropolitan governmental mechanisms were primarily "medieval", the crown providing "lordships", "grants of nobility or knighthood, and monetary rewards or exemptions to encourage private initiative" (154). Viceroys were installed in Mexico City (1535) and Lima (1544) reflecting the tension between private and crown power. Portugal was less inclined to regulation preferred a decentralized method of governance administered through "numerous councils" until late into the Iberian Atlantic period and a "separate colonial council" was only established in 1642, well over a century after Spain established its colonial administrative organs (156). Despite these differences, Iberian immigration to the colony increased throughout this period, especially for Spain, which meant a "cross-section of Spanish society... the vast majority peasants, artisans, labourers, and a few gentlemen" began to dominate the American colonies (152).
           Control of the indigenous population through the encomienda (tribute and forced labor of subjugated populations) proved especially lucrative for some settlers, who became private interests in competition with the crown. Such opposition grew, evidenced by rebellion in Peru in the 1540s, for example. Military conquest did not translate to “civil and ecclesiastical” control and monarchical governance was constant negotiation between “former indigenous leaders and nobles, municipal councils whose members formed a kind of urban patriciate, or prominent encomenderos, merchants, or landowners” (155). Additionally, especially for Spain, foreign competitors, piracy, and the contraband market required constant attention. Spanish colonial infrastructure was exploited by the French, Portuguese and English who "often [received] tacit aid from the local population and suborned officials" (160). These novel economic opportunities gave rise to novel social categories borne by the children of Spanish, indigenous and African interactions. New classes of "person[s] of mixed heritage", such as "mestizos" or "creoles" resulted in another interest group vying for "social position" (161). Despite the threats of novel economic and social competition, the major period of settlement was well established by 1540 and "by 1570 the main outlines of the colony had been defined" such that "foreign competitors had been eliminated" and local opposition had been destroyed or displaced (153).
Finally, the Iberian presence in the Atlantic was a part of more global Iberian presence with Portuguese ships in the Indian Ocean and Spanish presence across the Pacific toward China and in the Philippines (Manila was established in 1571). Additionally, both states relied on one another for geopolitical support: Spanish and Portuguese immigrants were the largest foreign European presences in the territory of either state; they shared and developed strategic ports for mutual benefit; they performed joint military ventures to secure mutual interests; and they also attempted to use the legal and political tools of the other nation, Portuguese appealing to the encomienda for instance, when it suited national economic interest. Together, Iberian cooperation and competition secured control of the silver, slave, and sugar markets of the Atlantic during this period. However, increased colonial economic power resulted in evermore frequent revolts and domestic problems meant that Spain had difficulty managing their colonial territories by the mid-17th Century (164). Portugal went onto focus on Brazilian sugar while Spain eventually recognized Portuguese independence amidst its own domestic and colonial troubles, unable to dominate that relationship as they had earlier in the Iberian Atlantic period. The latter part of the Iberian Atlantic period was the result of managerial problems, a decline in the profitability of sugar, increased foreign competition, and environmental trouble. Imperial control from Iberia was weaker and “local elites played an increasing role in defence, governance, the enactment of colonial policy, and in the control of the complex social hierarchies that the Iberians had created in their Atlantic empires” (165). Schwartz demonstrates how the economic, political, and military practices that secured the Iberian Atlantic were defined by cooperation and competition between nations and private interests producing a new and increasingly independent political and economic entity: the colony.

Extracted Annotations (2021-02-05, 1:39:41 p.m.)
"The marauders saw the Atlantic as an open sea in which they could seek riches as they pleased, unlike the Mediterranean or the Baltic seas, where regular trade prevailed." (Canny et al 2012:2)
"6) After the middle of the sixteenth century, single privateers gave way to whole squadrons harassing Spanish and Portuguese shipping or raiding settlements." (Canny et al 2012:2)
"Overall, what is striking is the haphazard, uncoordinated, contingent nature of colonization, featuring im­ mediate concerns and accidental openings, interrupted by warfare and internal strife. As anti-Iberian militancy was rarely matched by conquests, grand designs remained dead letters, and northerners had to resign themselves to settling places the Iberians had nev­ er occupied." (Canny et al 2012:4)
"Migration thus largely explains the increased size of the settlements by 1660, when some 8,000 Europeans had found a new abode in the Dutch settlements, around 16,000 in the French colonies, and more than 60,000 in the English" (Canny et al 2012:8)
"If the men planning colonies proclaimed that the Americas would yield a wide range of products that would sustain an immigrant population, the conditions faced by the first settlers were often dismal." (Canny et al 2012:9)
"While northern European governments needed guarantors of stable American colonies, colonial planners sought national grants of land. The solution was to establish (p. 177) pro­ prietary colonies, as had happened in Spanish and Portuguese America in the previous century." (Canny et al 2012:10)
"Trade and settlement were indeed often at odds, and not only in proprietary colonies. Merchants wanted to keep overhead costs to a minimum, preferring to save on defence, desiring free trade, and often failing to see the advantages of colonization." (Canny et al 2012:10)
"Religion also provided a framework for relations with blacks and Indians. The main mo­ tive for settlement in North America, according to contemporary French propaganda, was France's obligation to preach the gospel to all creatures throughout the world, to expel idolatry, and to 'polish the barbarous ways of the Gentiles'." (Canny et al 2012:11)
"Relations with natives were often the key to survival." (Canny et al 2012:12)
"English and Dutch ministers often strongly condemned concubi­ nage with Indians, Africans, or women of mixed race, yet everywhere northerners en­ tered into sexual relations with natives, due in part to the demographic profile of the Eu­ ropean immigrants" (Canny et al 2012:12)
"The propensity to miscegenation seems to have been greatest among the French in North America and smallest in the colonies of the English." (Canny et al 2012:12)
"By 1600, the northerners had as yet made little headway in their attempts to challenge the Iberian hold on the At­ lantic world." (Canny et al 2012:12)
"But little long-term harm was done to Iberian might. Spain's enemies, as one historian has put it, were 'driven to the fringes of Spain's American empire',33 and Portugal eventually managed to expel the Dutch and restore its power over Angola and Brazil." (Canny et al 2012:12)

(Note on) Klooster, Wim. The Northern European Atlantic World. Edited by Nicholas Canny and Philip Morgan. Vol. 1. Oxford University Press, 2012.
“The Northern European Atlantic Word” by Wim Klooster is an overview of the French, British and Dutch growth as imperial powers in the Atlantic World, from piracy to settler colonialism. At first, in the 16th century, their actions could be characterized as “predatory practice,” where instead of establishing a strong foothold in the Americas and Africa, they resorted to feeding off Spanish and Portuguese wealth by attacking their convoys. Indeed, as Klooster highlight, “The marauders saw the Atlantic as an open sea in which they could seek riches as they pleased, unlike the Mediterranean or the Baltic seas, where regular trade prevailed.”[1] During, the early 17th Century, the development of the fur trade in Northern America and the fisheries of the Northern Atlantic, led to the establishment of settler colonies. With the foundation of New France, New England, and New Netherlands, the three Northern European powers chartered companies to exploit the natural resource and colonize the land. The monopolies given to those companies set in motion a system where the national government minimized their expenses and risks by relying on third parties. On the downside, as the author points out: “Trade and settlement were indeed often at odds(…). Merchants wanted to keep overhead costs to a minimum, preferring to save on defence, desiring free trade, and often failing to see the advantages of colonization.”[2]In West Africa, the Northerners shied away from settler colonialism, favoring instead the establishment of trading posts, as they were dependent on local African authorities for their protection. Those new business ventures in the Atlantic World helped spread Christianity to the New World and Africa. Far from being only on the business side, these relations with the native populations proved instrumental to the Northerners’ survival, as the newcomers relied on them for food and supplies. Interestingly, the attitude toward miscegenation varied widely between Europeans, from abhorred in the British colonies to more widespread and accepted in the French North American colonies (although it does not imply an absence of racial hierarchy or fear of assimilation). By the midway point of the 17th century, Northerners had established settler colonies and trading posts all over the Americas and Africa, challenging but not permanently damaging Portuguese and Spanish imperial hegemony. Lastly, we must keep in mind that according to Klooster, the colonial enterprise    is contingent by nature and the result of multiple unpredictable variables, featuring “immediate concerns and accidental openings, interrupted by warfare and internal strife.”[3]
 
 
[1] Klooster, Wim. The Northern European Atlantic World. Edited by Nicholas Canny and Philip Morgan. Vol. 1. Oxford University Press, 2012, 165.
[2]Ibid, 177.[3]Ibid, 168.

[1] Klooster, Wim. The Northern European Atlantic World. Edited by Nicholas Canny and Philip Morgan. Vol. 1. Oxford University Press, 2012, 165.
[2]Ibid, 177.[3]Ibid, 168.

Canny and Morgan's introduction outlines the new relations that emerged between late 15th and early 19th century. While addressing the social, political, and economic developments, they also challenge historical accounts that engage with the Atlantic History in dichotomous narratives. They argue that the collection of essays to which they are writing an introduction refuse to incorporate Eurocentric model of history in that: 1) they refuse to take European History as central and the 'Overseas History' as an extension, and 2) the historical changes that has happened over the specified time period is not explained teleologically under the rubric of  transitioning from colony to labor (p. 2). The articles, they argue, push back against the narratives that disregard the role played by the alliances formed with native populations in the European conquests. Moreover, the articles complicate the narratives regarding massive population loss suffered by the Native American populations as they show that the exploitation of people and ecologies were as determining as the warfare and Old World diseases (p. 3).
Canny and Morgan engage with Braudel's argument on the key role played by the climatic and geomorphologic conditions in shaping social and economic relations. They show how human agency and scientific developments were as important in shaping the politics and developments around the Atlantic. They discuss the different manifestations of state involvement, ethnic and racial composition, gender balance, shape of the settlements across the Atlantic world, highlighting how these differences are intricately tied to a dynamic set of sociopolitical factors. Despite the differences, they argue, the 18th century witnessed a gradual integration around the Atlantic world, especially in the economic sphere, in relation to the technological developments (in shipping and marine infrastructures, commercial systems, mapping). The increased movement across the ocean also facilitated political and legal reorganization which was complicated by the frictions emerging through wars and revolutions. Canny and Morgan especially highlight the role played by the Seven Years War, 1756-63, and the American and Haitian Revolutions in contributing to the segmentation of the Atlantic world. Despite this political segmentation, they argue, the  development of steam-powered transport in the 19th century, made possible a global market that links different commercial segments directly.

Summary of Matthew Edney, “Knowledge and Cartography in the Early Atlantic,” The Oxford Handbook of the Atlantic World: 1450-1850 (2011).
 
Edney’s chapter, “Knowledge and Cartography in the Early Atlantic,” works to explain the ways in which oceanic pilots and land-based geographers differed in their approaches to mapmaking in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, how the concept of a unified “Atlantic” emerged from culturally varied understandings of the oceans west and south of Europe, and the varied meanings and implications of mapping in the Americas; throughout this chapter, Edney examines the “production, circulation, and consumption of spatial information” concerning the Atlantic world (1).
Edney explains that in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries there were essentially two groups of chart makers: retired and active pilots who “made charts generally intended for practical use,” and “specialized land-bound chart makers [who] were more responsive to the intellectual and political needs of princes” (5).  This second type made maps with geography in mind, particularly the curvature of the earth, but this resulted in unwieldy and difficult to use charts that were ultimately impractical for pilots. 
The royalty and corporations, such as the VOC and WIC, who paid for these various expeditions were very much concerned with the geography of place and hired chart makers “to reconcile the logs and establish a coherent archive of navigational data;” these “geographical anxieties” resulted in the formation of offices such as the Armazém de Guiné e India and the Casa de la Contratación (7).  Edney notes that the “official and corporate attempts to control marine knowledge could only encompass those portions amenable to inscription and archiving,” and that “oral portions of pilot lore remained in circulation beyond” the control of metropole officials (7-8). 
This article also examines the evolution of European oceanic mapping throughout the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries.  It wasn’t until seventeenth c that the Dutch and the English had adopted the term “Atlantic,” using it “as a synonym for the Western Ocean,” and ultimately the “international adoption of the modern and internationally held concept on an extensive Atlantic” didn’t fully emerge until the nineteenth c.
Edney also explains the importance and involvement of Indigenous peoples’ oral accounts of terrestrial geography to colonial mapmaking; likewise, the maps that emerge about the colonial Americas and the African continent speak volumes about the relationships between European colonizers and the Indigenous communities.  For example, for much of this period the maps concerning the African continent almost exclusively depicted the coast and not the interior, simply because coastal African polities “restricted European traders to the coast,” thus “controlling the supply of slaves and other commodities, including knowledge of the interior” (15).
Ultimately, the maps that emerge from colonial spaces could, much like the early fifteenth century oceanic maps, be split into two groups with very different goals.  Edney explains that while “local inhabitants mapped in order to assert the existence of a community and the preserve rights” accorded to property and land ownership, “surveyors from outside the local communities mapped in order to impose a sense of order and coherence on behalf of their employers” (15-16).  In other words, one method worked to resist imperial control while the other worked to impose it.

"Two stages in the making of the Atlantic world need to be distinguished; the age of explo­ration, when the geography of the two oceans was yet to be determined, and the age of exploitation which followed" 
Difficulty of seafaring is the return voyage.
"The Atlantic world was opened up and exploited by navigators with only a rough and ready understanding of what they were doing." 
"Different people opened up different Atlantics, divided by space and time, which were not conceptually united until the sixteenth or even seventeenth centuries. Until then it is most realistic not to speak of a single Atlantic world, but of a series of Atlantic routes, outward and homeward."
"The first of all the European Atlantics"= vikings
Early 14th c, Genoese and Catalans in the Canaries, something of an extension of the Mediterranean world. 
Europeans figured out the Atlantic wind system in the 15th c. Knowledge of wind system "taught seamen to make long ocean passages by exploiting circular wind systems to get in­ to the whereabouts, and latitudes, of their destinations. Like the Norwegians in the far North 400 years before, the Portuguese had discovered that the secret of long-distance passage-making is to keep far away from land."
15th c, Portuguese looking for gold along coast of Africa
Also in the 15th c--figuring out celestial navigation. "The king (John II) convened an expert panel of astronomers who proposed using an astrolabe to ‘weigh’ the noon altitude of the sun, and compiled the necessary declination tables. Now a method was available by which latitude could be fixed anywhere in the world; the crucial intellectual tool which allowed European seamen to break out of the Atlantic into the Indian Ocean and beyond"
three-masted ships also developed in the 15th c. Sail and rigging systems refined in the 16th and 17th c. By the 16th, "a typical Spanish ship of 300 tons...could be handled by a crew of fifty."
Portuguese in the Atlantic "long-term, centrally planned operation ex­ploiting the best scientific knowledge of the day."
Columbus was deeply mistaken about seafaring. "He did not sight the main land of South America until his third voyage in 1498, when a bungled altitude of Polaris persuaded him that he was sailing uphill and was about to enter the Earthly Paradise."
Ultimately, Vasco da Gama wrecked Columbus's reputation "bringing news of a practicable route to the real Indies, and an accurate estimate of the size of the world which immediately exploded all Columbus' fantasies." 
Possibility that English fishermen had reached the Newfoundland Banks. "it is therefore possible that the 1498 voyage from Bristol to Newfound­land by the Italian seaman known to English history as John Cabot was more in the na­ture of confirmation than exploration." Fishermen and whalers from number of European nations start going over there.
Mid 16th c, "Atlantic world was conceptually united" understanding that the Americas were not Asia.
Getting in and out of port was a problem for seafaring ships because of their size and rigging. In the 19th c iron shipbuilding and steam tugs made porting easier and "made possible the rapid increase in ship size which under­ pinned the last golden century of commercial sail"
The wind and current systems gave Spanish "a huge advantage in settling the Caribbean basin, for the transatlantic passage from Seville and back is swift and easy." Same for Portuguese in the South Atlantic.
"the great challenge" in navigation was finding longitude. one method relied on measurements of lunar distance, another on the chronometer (highly accurate time piece), though they were expensive and not widely used. "It is arguable that the great breakthrough in practical navigation was neither the chronometer nor lu­nars, but Thomas Sumner's method of obtaining a ‘position line’, first published in 1847, which allowed the navigator to get a working fix on the basis of fleeting observations of any two heavenly bodies (or the same body at intervals of time), at any hour of the day or night."
Uncertainty of longitude, and sometimes of latitude, a reality of Atlantic travel. Lisbon was the easiest port to find in Europe. "This alone is a powerful explanation for the lead taken by the Portuguese and then the Spa­ niards in oceanic navigation. By contrast, English ports in general, and London in particu­ lar, are exceptionally difficult to reach under sail from the open sea."
"The social history of Atlantic seafaring, especially in its earliest phases, is largely unwrit­ ten. We can only guess what it meant to venture on long ocean passages for men who had never before been out of sight of land for more than a few days."
"The study of Atlantic navigation raises as many questions as it answers. It seems to ac­ count for the early success of Portugal and Spain, but also seems to make almost impossi­ ble the rise to prominence in international trade of such remote and unfavoured ports as London and Amsterdam."

Whitehead, Neil L. 2012. Native Americans and Europeans: Early Encounters in the Caribbean and along the Atlantic Coast. The Oxford Handbook of the Atlantic World: 1450-1850. 
DOI: 10.1093/oxfordhb/9780199210879.013.0004
 
Neil Whitehead’s article looks at the “temporally episodic and geographically uneven” encounters between Indigenous people and Europeans beginning in the 16th century. Tracing the geographic points of arrival for the Spanish, Portuguese, Dutch, French, and British into the Americas and the cultural exchanges between these groups, Whitehead argues that the “early encounters were a multifaceted event, not just a linear transition from ‘traditional’ to ‘modernity,’ or from ‘native’ to ‘colonial’” (14). The geographical focus centers on the first encounters that encompass the Caribbean Atlantic to South America (Amazon and Orinoco).
The Caribbean region and its people were the first to encounter the Europeans, which produces a new political and economic response on the part of indigenous people. The conquests of the Greater and Lesser Antilles, Puerto Rico, and Trinidad in the sixteenth century by Spain saw the introduction of exploitation and a new political status for indigenous groups that was contested by religious sects like Franciscans in Cumana and Dominican missions at Chirivichi. Similarly, in the Brazilian Atlantic, the encounters between Indigenous peoples, Portuguese, and French introduced new forms of political status based on the exploitation of peoples and natural resources. The Atlantic-coast forests became a source of production as brazilwood, which can create red dye, was harvested leading to the creation of a “factory system” (4). In 1506, the Portuguese crown created “royal factories” along the Atlantic coast which eventually “required a different and less permissive strategy towards the native population” (5). 
Spanish colonization had centered on the Caribbean and Peru. The Amazon River was a site for contestation between Indigenous peoples, the Spanish, Portuguese, and Dutch. The Dutch made their presence felt with the establishment of the West India Company in 1616. The reliance on brazilwood as a trade commodity created military incursions and rivalries. The arrival of religious sects, such as Spanish Protestants, in the sixteenth century further signaled a shift in political status for Native peoples which resulted in the destruction of their autonomous form of living by the seventeenth century. As the Indigenous population was eliminated from the land through colonization and settlement, they also were the primary victims of epidemics and viruses. By the seventeenth century, Europeans had reached North America further shaping and re-shaping life along the Atlantic coast.
The ways of life for Indigenous people in the Americas had changed dramatically from the first Encounter. Skills, specialties, and knowledge were lost as were regional trade networks for Native Americans. The patterns of colonization and settlement transported various contexts throughout South and North America, creating fragile alliances between Indigenous peoples and Europeans. From the Caribbean Islands to the Amazon River in South America, commodities like brazilwood, introduced new forms of extraction, such as the “factory system, and political status’ intertwined with religious sects. The links created through these interactions signalled the first encounter for a region and peoples with “modernity” (15).

Summary: David Northrup, Africans, Early European Contacts, and the Emergent Diaspora 
Benin. Further south in West Central Africa, the kingdoms of Kongo and Ndongo also developed fruitful relations with Portugal with letters and delegations exchanged but later have to share This article entitled Africans, Early European Contacts, and the Emergent Diaspora is about the first two centuries (1400-1600) of contacts between coastal Africans and Europeans in the Atlantic world. The article points to three overlapping areas of encounter such as diplomatic relations, commercial exchange, and intercultural and cross-cultural exchanges.
The description of the diplomatic relations starts with showing the apprehension of Africans who thought “Europeans might be evil spirit or alien creatures with supernatural powers” which later subsided with the realization that Europeans are human beings The establishment of diplomatic relations was accompanied with a demand to convert to Christianity notably in the Senegalese kingdom of Jolof where Bumi Jeleen, heir to the throne converted to Christianity in a baptismal ceremony in Portugal and benefited from the military support of the Portuguese against his half-brother. Similarly, in Akan speaking kingdoms, the Portuguese and later the Dutch established themselves in fortified outposts for a mutual beneficial trade that led to a perpetual conflictual relation. In the kingdom of Benin, the relation with the Portuguese led to the dispatch of African delegate who was received as an ambassador and allowed a fruitful relation between Benin and Portugal. Other Europeans such as French, Dutch, and English later established similar diplomatic relations with the kingdom of power with the growing Portuguese presence.
As far as the commercial exchanges are concerned, “Portuguese crown claimed exclusive control over all trade with Atlantic Africa.” The Portuguese controlled the islands of Cape Verde and Sao Tome and Principe which gave them a monopoly that was later contested by other Europeans. Africans exported gold, sugar, pepper, slaves, wild animals, forest products, and some manufactured goods. This was possible due to the diverted trade from the trans Saharan trade to the Atlantic world. According to the author’s estimate of gold export, “between 25,000 and 27,000 ounces a year from 1471 to 1600 and over 32,000 ounces a year in the first half of the seventeenth century” were exported to Europe. Juula Muslim merchants were instrumental in diverting gold trade from Western Sudan to the coast. Benin was known for the trade of different variety of pepper with Portugal and later attracted other Europeans. The following centuries saw a rise in slave trade. Europeans on the other hand introduced sugar can, cotton, indigo, tobacco, maize, different textiles, copper, brass, iron bars, metal tools, utensils, devices, few firearms, and cowries and manillas used as currencies.
For cultural interactions, there was a notable spread of Christianity on the coast and in the inland trading routes. However, there was a limited cultural influence on Europeans. European languages were learned to facilitate commercial transactions and other exchanges. Portuguese was the first lingua franca followed later by other European languages. Intermarriages between European men and African women generated what the author calls ‘Eurafrican communities’ leading to the creation of Crioulo language which is a combination of Portuguese and West African language. The spread of both Roman Catholicism and protestant faiths was notable. The focus was on a top-down conversion of the rulers and the elites which succeeded in spreading both faith in West and central west Africa. The underlining feature of these conversions was that Africans “understood their new faith in terms of old cosmologies.”

• the essays are grouped under three themes: 1. Fashioning of the Atlantic worlds over the course of 15th to 17th centuries; 2. each of these worlds got incorporated into a broader, 'a single functioning Atlantic world' through 18th C; 3. this world has become so interconnected that the collapse in one part led to a disruption in the other. p. 2
  • refusing to 1. represent 'Overseas History' as an extension of European history, 2. narrate the historical changes as teleological stories of transitioning from 'colony to nation' p. 2
  • showing that the success of the conquests were due to the local alliances with 'native enemies of dominant groups'; and also demonstrating that the Native American population loss was due to not only warfare and Old World diseases, but also exploitation and destruction of the environment. p. 3
  • the history of native populations and habitats is not one of termination, but of continuous change and adaptation (genetic intermixtures, shifts in territories, new political alliances, exchange of technologies, environmental destruction, population losses). The Native American loss of influence was not total; they had enduring influence on political, legal codes and procedures, in religious sphere. p. 3
  • Until the 18th C, the European presence was tentative in the Atlantic coast of Africa - only after 1700, when a demand for labor increased in America and Native American workforces collapsed, "trade in slaves became a principle interest of European merchants" - racial and political mixtures emerging in the parts of Americas where slavery was common 4

Canny and Morgan's introduction outlines the new relations that emerged between late 15th and early 19th century. While addressing the social, political, and economic developments, they also challenge historical accounts that engage with the Atlantic History in dichotomous narratives. They argue that the collection of essays to which they are writing an introduction refuse to incorporate Eurocentric model of history in that: 1) they refuse to take European History as central and the 'Overseas History' as an extension, and 2) the historical changes that has happened over the specified time period is not explained teleologically under the rubric of  transitioning from colony to labor (p. 2). The articles, they argue, push back against the narratives that disregard the role played by the alliances formed with native populations in the European conquests. Moreover, the articles complicate the narratives regarding massive population loss suffered by the Native American populations as they show that the exploitation of people and ecologies were as determining as the warfare and Old World diseases (p. 3).
Canny and Morgan engage with Braudel's argument on the key role played by the climatic and geomorphologic conditions in shaping social and economic relations. They show how human agency and scientific developments were as important in shaping the politics and developments around the Atlantic. They discuss the different manifestations of state involvement, ethnic and racial composition, gender balance, shape of the settlements across the Atlantic world, highlighting how these differences are intricately tied to a dynamic set of sociopolitical factors. Despite the differences, they argue, the 18th century witnessed a gradual integration around the Atlantic world, especially in the economic sphere, in relation to the technological developments (in shipping and marine infrastructures, commercial systems, mapping). The increased movement across the ocean also facilitated political and legal reorganization which was complicated by the frictions emerging through wars and revolutions. Canny and Morgan especially highlight the role played by the Seven Years War, 1756-63, and the American and Haitian Revolutions in contributing to the segmentation of the Atlantic world. Despite this political segmentation, they argue, the  development of steam-powered transport in the 19th century, made possible a global market that links different commercial segments directly.

This article is the introduction to The Oxford Handbook of the Atlantic World and thus covers a wide array of information as it seeks to address some of the larger themes of the volume. The 38-author collection of essays covers the history of the Atlantic world. Specifically, the movement of people and things across the Atlantic ocean and how this movement bolstered some societies while destroying others. It is primarily focused on the late fifteenth century through the nineteenth and concerns the themes of emergence, consolidation, integration, and disintegration. One of the larger themes that the introduction addresses is the emerging emphasis on Native American and African agency. In contrast to previous scholarship that used a Eurocentric model of analysis, scholars in this volume are focused on demonstrating how Native Americans and Africans played a role in shaping the Atlantic World through their negotiations with Europeans. Rather than a story of victimization, Canny and Morgan label their stories as ones of survival (p. 3). Another departure from previous work is the rejection of environmental determinism in shaping the Atlantic World. The introduction stresses the differences between scholars of other oceanic trading networks such as Fernand Braudel, a notable determinist and scholar of the Mediterranean, and Atlantic World scholars which place most of the onus on human agency and interaction—though not completely. This article introduces the importance of wind and tides in designating Western Europe and Brazil as the two primary centers for slave-trading on the Atlantic Ocean. This became increasingly true in the late eighteenth century when greater advances in knowledge and technology allowed for faster ships and thus greater movement across the Atlantic. Coupled with desires for greater colonization, this period saw the advent of a common seaborne culture. To conclude, the introduction provides a brief overview of the role of war in shaping the Atlantic World and ultimately, how conflict and revolutions contributed to its demise by the end of the nineteenth century.

Land of Verzin / Guanabara Bay / 1519 /

After we had passed the equinoctial line going 
south, we lost the north star, and hence we sailed 
south south-west until [we reached] a land called 
the land of Verzin which lies in 23^ degrees of 
the Antarctic Pole [i.e.y south latitude]. It is the 
land extending from the cape of Santo Augustino, 
which lies in 8 degrees of the same pole. There we 
got a plentiful refreshment of fowls, potatoes 
[batate] many sweet pine-apples - in truth the most 
delicious fruit that can be found - the flesh of the 
anta which resembles beef, sugarcane, and innumerable other things, which I shall not mention in 
order not to be prolix. 
/17
